docs.lead_paragraph: Where have all the Lassies gone? Who can forget that noble collie who had her own show on Sunday-night TV and was a kid's best friend, there for the hugging when you needed her to be? She was an honorary member of the show's perfect nuclear family -- the whey-faced Timmy, played by Jon Provost; his earnest mother, played by June Lockhart; and his levelheaded father, played by Hugh Reilly. But it was also abundantly clear that no one was thinking of inviting Lassie in for a snack of milk and Lick 'n Crunch treats (Oreo-style cookies from Three Dog Bakery, made with carob instead of chocolate, which is bad for dogs) or of decking her out in a Swarovski-crystal heart-shaped dog tag, or of painting her nails with Opi's Pawlish. You can be just as sure that Timmy wasn't saving up his allowance to buy Lassie a $14 squeaky toy Chewy Vuitton or Jimmy Chew and that his mother wasn't stretching the household budget to cover Le Chien et Le Chat cedar-scented laundry detergent. No, Lassie belonged to an honorable but almost-extinct breed of household pet, one that knew its place in the family of man. She would never have been caught dead sleeping in a customized $400 white-crackle painted dog bed with toile linens -- would never have been caught dead sleeping anywhere but outside the farmhouse screen door, keeping an ear cocked for strange sounds.
docs.snippet: Enough Hermès collars and spalike kennels. A pet is no person.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sara Martowski, a daughter of Jeanne G. Martowski and David W. Martowski of Manhattan, was married last evening to Scott William Barek, a son of Deborah Brower Barek and Dr. Dennis Barek of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Seth M. Limmer performed the ceremony at the Angel Orensanz Foundation Center for the Arts in Manhattan. Mrs. Barek, 31, works in Manhattan as the business analyst and project manager for the ClearForest Corporation, a company in Waltham, Mass., that analyzes business information. She graduated cum laude from Middlebury College.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE numbers are in, and Long Island voters now have two weeks to decide whether to approve their local school district budgets. In the aftermath of financial scandals in the Roslyn and William Floyd districts, it could be an uneasy two weeks for school officials, who are hoping that the vote will not be a repeat of last year's, when 46 out of 124 budgets were defeated, a failure rate of 37 percent. Monday was the deadline for districts to post their final proposed budgets and tax levies and their projected enrollments for the 2005-6 school year. The budgets will be put to a vote on May 17.

headline.main: School Budgets Are Going Up At Slower Pace

docs.snippet: THE numbers are in, and Long Island voters now have two weeks to decide whether to approve their local school district budgets.     In the aftermath of financial scandals in the Roslyn and William Floyd districts, it could be an uneasy two weeks for...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTEREST rates are ticking up while stock prices are trending down, eroding 401(k) savings. The president says that the Social Security system is in trouble, suggesting that the retirement age must be increased or that benefits must be scaled back for the well-off. General Motors wants to rein in skyrocketing health costs for retirees. Retired coal miners have lost company-paid health insurance in bankruptcy proceedings. Even robust Fortune 500 companies are groaning under the weight of spiraling retirement costs.

headline.main: '55 and Out' Comes Home To Roost

docs.snippet: For many middle-age, middle-class workers, retirement planning has become an exercise in high anxiety - except for public employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a baby boomer myself, I can be blunt: We boomers won't be remembered as the ''Greatest Generation.'' Rather, we'll be scorned as the ''Greediest Generation.'' Our influence has been huge. When boomer blood raged with hormones, we staged the sexual revolution and popularized the Pill. Now, with those hormones fading, we've popularized Viagra.
docs.snippet: We boomers won't be remembered as the "Greatest Generation." Rather, we'll be scorned as the "Greediest Generation."
